basics.name: Richard Colwell
basics.summary: Materials scientist focused on creating impactful, sustainability-driven solutions

work.name: Amazon Worldwide Sustainability
work.summary: Led materials testing to evaluate novel post-consumer recycled and biodegradable polymer materials to support carbon reduction efforts.

work.name: Tender Food
work.summary: Designed and conducted experiments to evaluate formulations and post- processing treatments for novel plant-based meat products. Pioneered a new platform for sample preparation to lower raw material costs by >50% and sample preparation time by >90% while reducing carbon footprint. Developed an LCA model for carbon footprint and ingredient hotspots.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Herbold Fellow
awards.awarder: University of Washington College of Engineering
awards.summary: Supports graduate students in data science and computation within the College of Engineering, awarded for academic excellence.

awards.title: Graduate Research Fellow
awards.summary: Supports outstanding graduate students in STEM with potential for significant research impact.

awards.title: ARCS Fellow
awards.summary: Honors academically distinguished U.S. graduate students pursuing advanced STEM degrees.

awards.title: Ted Golfinopoulos Team Building Award
awards.summary: Recognizes “commitment to students’ team building, relationship building, and remarkable assistance in students’ learning process,” as decided by students vote in MEET, a CS and entrepreneurship education program for Palestinian and Israeli high school students.

awards.title: Max Goldman Excellence in Education Award
awards.summary: Celebrates “commitment to exceptional teaching and fostering learning,” as decided by students' vote in MEET. Inaugural recipient, selected from 15 instructors and TAs for the summer.

publications.name: What’s lost, what’s left, what’s next: Lessons learned from the lived experiences of teachers during the pandemic
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
